currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game nig

We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.

While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage som

We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting

If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. I

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small scr

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near

Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outsi

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.

 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blast

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to bi

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shu

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if

While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen f

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.

If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.

If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting

While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and

While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about chang

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change

If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help you

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.

We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional he

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of y

While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, an

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Ma

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it

If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.

It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with pap

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Ma

We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Make things real. W

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.

It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Make things real. We can get over thi

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it.

Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Make things real. We can get over this

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Make things real. We can get over this dark time togeth

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should opt for a balance. We should use screens if they help reduce danger of catching Delta Covid. We also need to maintain relationships in real life. While screens did, indeed win, we need to involve ourselves with others in real life. We need to give hugs when it's safe to do so, visit people see them in actuality. We need to keep close connections. Removing ourselves from others damages us. It prevents us from deepening our relationships and cementing our life.
We need to be aware of the dangers of screen time.
 We need to monitor our usage and do what we can to avoid becoming addicted to screens. We need to maintain a strong self control with avoiding being pulled in with gaming, too much texting, and avoiding real events, if it's safe to meet in person. When people invite you over, if it's safe to go, say yes. Take care to change one activity each day. Maintain close friendships, don't neglect to go for a meal with someone, host a game night, or do something fun. Make a sort of game of it. 


If you're feeling isolated, try to get out and about.
 Do something fun, encourage someone who you see in person. While outside, introduce yourself. Make a new friend, in real life. Avoid sitting home alone in the dark. It's a bad sign that you are so focused on a small screen and can't determine what's happening near you. When you are outside try to avoid listening full time to blasting music. Listen to birds, hear your neighbors say hello. Make things more real. Make your life real. Shun the virtual if you can. Do screen free time at work or at home.  For goodness sake if you meet someone or are at work and in a meeting, turn OFF your devices. Be wholly present. 
If you have a child, monitor their screen time.
 Try to be positive and bring about change. It will help your emotional health, the health, emotionally of your family, and your friends.  Make a goal, write it down, with paper, Do it now. Make things real. We can get over this dark time together. We are strong
